edge: Polanski produced and directed the film The Pianist.
Brody starred in the film The Pianist.
Harwood wrote the script for the film The Pianist.
The film is based on Szpilman's autobiographical book.
The Pianist is a co-production between France, the United Kingdom, Germany and Poland.
The film premiered at the Cannes Film Festival in 2002.
The Pianist won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival in 2002.
In September 1939, Władysław Szpilman, a Polish-Jewish pianist, was playing live on the radio in Warsaw when the station was besieged during Nazi Germany's invasion of Poland.

node_2: britain and france's declaration of war on germany
edge: After escaping the attack, Szpilman rejoiced with his family at home when he learned that Britain and France had declared war on Germany.
Jews were soon prevented from working or owning businesses, and were also forced to wear blue Star of David armbands.
Szpilman and his family were forced from their home into the isolated and overcrowded Warsaw Ghetto.
Conditions in the Warsaw Ghetto only got worse, with food shortages leading to starvation.
The constant threat of Schutzstaffel (SS) brutality.
On one occasion, he saw a young boy being savagely beaten by a guard while trying to crawl through a gap in the ghetto wall; the boy was dead by the time Szpilman could pull him through.
At dinner, Szpilman and his family witnessed the SS killing another family in an apartment across the street during a round-up, including throwing an elderly wheelchair-bound man from the window.
On 16 August 1942, Szpilman and his family were about to be transported to Treblinka extermination camp as part of Operation Reinhard; previously they had failed to acquire a German work certificate.
On 16 August 1942, Szpilman and his family were about to be transported to Treblinka extermination camp as part of Operation Reinhard; previously they had failed to acquire a German work certificate.
A friend from the Jewish Ghetto Police led Szpilman away from his family at the Umschlagplatz as he was about to board the train.
After being transported to an unknown location, Szpilman became a slave labourer.
Szpilman helped the resistance by smuggling weapons into the ghetto hidden inside bags of food, on one occasion narrowly avoiding a suspicious guard.
Szpilman watched from his window as the uprising which he aided, unfolded and then ultimately failed in April 1943.
After a neighbor discovered Szpilman and attempted to persecute him, he fled the apartment.
Dorota provided Szpilman a hiding place after his old friend abandoned him and he suffered from jaundice.
Dorota and her husband visited Szpilman the last time, providing him a doctor to treat his illness.

Szpilman recovers and the Warsaw Uprising begins. The Home Army attacks the Schutzpolizei building across the street from the apartment, while Szpilman's hideout is destroyed by a German tank shell, forcing him to flee and hide in an abandoned hospital. Over the course of the following months, Warsaw is destroyed.
Szpilman hides in an abandoned hospital after his hideout is destroyed by a German tank shell during the Warsaw Uprising.
Szpilman reaches an empty house where he finds a can of pickled cucumbers while wandering through the city's ruins.
Hosenfeld discovers Szpilman and learns that he is a pianist. He asks Szpilman to play on a grand piano in the house, and Szpilman manages to play Chopin's 'Ballade No. 1 in G minor'.
Hosenfeld lets Szpilman hide in the attic of the house, which is used as his center of operations, and supplies food for him.
Hosenfeld leaves Szpilman with a large supply of food and his greatcoat to keep warm before retreating from the Soviet offensive.
Narrowly survives an ambush by several People's Army troops who mistook him for a German after Warsaw is liberated.
Meets Szpilman for the last time and promises to listen to him on Polish Radio after the war before retreating from the Soviet offensive.

In Spring 1945, surviving concentration camp inmate Hosenfeld approached Szpilman, a fellow inmate and violinist, in a Soviet camp holding captured German soldiers. Hosenfeld requested Szpilman to rescue him as he knew his whereabouts.
After the war, Szpilman resumed his career at the Polish Radio and performed Chopin's 'Grand Polonaise' with an orchestra to a large prestigious audience.

The story had deep connections with director Roman Polanski because his father almost died in the camps, but they reunited after the end of World War II. However, Hosenfeld died in Soviet captivity in 1952.
At the Polish Radio, Szpilman performed Chopin's 'Grand Polonaise' with an orchestra to a large prestigious audience.
Director Roman Polanski escaped from the Kraków Ghetto as a child after the death of his mother during World War II. He ended up living in a Polish farmer's barn until the war's end.
Used to create the ruined city for The Pianist as they were going to be destroyed anyway.

node_2: first scene shot at the studio
edge: The complex and technically demanding scene in which Szpilman witnesses the ghetto uprising.
Chosen for filming because of its abundance of original buildings. The art department built onto these original buildings, re-creating World War II-era Poland with signs and posters from the period.
The Umschlagplatz scene where Szpilman, his family, and hundreds of other Jews wait to be taken to the extermination camps was filmed at the National Defence University of Warsaw.

The film 'illustrates' the theme of war and bigotry, as it relates to the Holocaust experience. Michael Wilmington of the Chicago Tribune stated that this film may signal Polanski's artistic redemption.
The film is a powerful statement on war, inhumanity, and art's redemption. Michael Wilmington of the Chicago Tribune called it the best dramatic feature he has seen on the Holocaust experience.
The film may signal Polanski's artistic redemption, as stated by Michael Wilmington of the Chicago Tribune. This theme is also proved through the film.
Richard Schickel of Time magazine called the film a 'raw, unblinkable film', citing its harsh objectivity.

node_2: refusal to seek our tears, our sympathies.
edge: Richard Schickel of Time magazine also stated that we admire this film for its harsh objectivity and refusal to seek our tears, our sympathies.
Mick LaSalle of the San Francisco Chronicle mentioned moments of irony in the film.
Mick LaSalle of the San Francisco Chronicle also cited moments of ambiguity in the film.
Mick LaSalle of the San Francisco Chronicle noted a scene where we finally get a look at Warsaw and see a panorama of destruction, a world of color bombed into black-and-white devastation.
Mick LaSalle of the San Francisco Chronicle stated that in the course of showing us a struggle for survival, the film also gives us humanity.
A.O. Scott of The New York Times compared Szpilman to one of Samuel Beckett's gaunt existential clowns in the bombed-out landscape.
A.O. Scott of The New York Times compared Szpilman's situation to a barren and bombed-out landscape.
A.O. Scott of The New York Times compared Szpilman to someone clutching a jar of pickles in the barren and bombed-out landscape.

node_1: szpilman's encounter with a music-loving german officer
edge: A.O. Scott of The New York Times felt that Szpilman's encounter with a music-loving German officer courted sentimentality by associating the love of art with moral decency.
A.O. Scott of The New York Times mentioned that the Nazis themselves, steeped in Beethoven and Wagner, definitively refuted the equation of love of art with moral decency.
Universal released the film on HD-DVD on January 8, 2008.
Optimum Home Entertainment released The Pianist to the European market on Blu-ray on September 13, 2010. This was the second release of the film on Blu-ray.
The initial release of The Pianist on Blu-ray had issues with subtitles. It lacked subtitles for spoken German dialogue.
Optimum Home Entertainment released The Pianist as part of their StudioCanal Collection on September 13, 2010.
The StudioCanal Collection version of The Pianist included the featurette 'A Story of Survival'.
The StudioCanal Collection version also included several interviews with the makers of the film and Szpilman's relatives.
Shout Factory released The Pianist on Blu-Ray in the US for the first time on July 13, 2021.
In 2023, The Pianist was completely restored from the original negative by StudioCanal and DI Factory with the assistance of cinematographer Pawel Edelman.
The restored version of The Pianist was released on 4K UHD by StudioCanal in Germany, France, and the UK.
